datafield.subfield: The collection documents the life and career of violinist Henryk Szeryng (1918-1988) who was also known as a teacher, patron of the arts and cultural ambassador. The collection contains printed and holograph manuscript scores, writings, teaching materials, correspondence, personal and business papers, performance files and programs, photographs, clippings, scrapbooks, publicity material, awards, and books.

titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Henryk Szeryng Collection 1933-1988 (bulk 1960-1988)
did.langmaterial: Collection material primarily in English, French, German, and Spanish
did.abstract: The collection documents the life and career of violinist Henryk Szeryng (1918-1988) who was also known as a teacher, patron of the arts and cultural ambassador. The collection contains printed and holograph manuscript scores, writings, teaching materials, correspondence, personal and business papers, performance files and programs, photographs, clippings, scrapbooks, publicity material, awards, and books.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: People
controlaccess.persname: Paganini, Nicolò, 1782-1840. Concertos, violin, orchestra, no. 3, E major; arr.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Most of the items in this collection were given by Waltraud Szeryng, Henryk's widow, in 1990. Other materials have been received from Gerhild Baron, Andree Desautels, Angela Lalauni, Gilles Lefebvre, and Marie-Anne de Valmalete.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Henryk Szeryng Collection was processed by Elaine Phelps in 1992. George Kipper coded the finding aid for EAD in 2010.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Books that relate to Szeryng's musical interests and/or contain noteworthy inscriptions have been retained in the collection, but the remaining books have been transferred to other divisions within the Library.
Recordings received as part of the collection were transferred to the Library of Congress, Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division.
A complete listing of the transferred items is on file in the Music Division.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Materials from the Henryk Szeryng Collection are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Henryk Szeryng Collection is open to research.
Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Henryk Szeryng Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born in Zelazowa Wola, Poland
Begins studying piano and hamony with his mother
Studys violin with Maurice Frenkel (student of Leopold Auer)
Continues violin study in Berlin with Willy Hess
Studies with Carl Flesch in Berlin and Baden-Baden at the suggestion of Bronislaw Huberman
Gives first public performances in Warsaw, Bucharest, Vienna and Paris

Studies composition in Paris with Nadia Boulanger; also studies the Humanities (i.e., Ancient History, Philology, and Philosophy); becomes acquainted with Georges Enesco, Igor Stravinsky, Maurice Ravel and other prominent musicians in Paris
Decorated with the Order of "Cultural Merit" by the Queen Mother of Romania
Enters Paris Conservatory, studying with Gabriel Bouillon; brief study with Jacques Thibaud
Graduates with First Prize from the Paris Conservatory
Moves to London; joins Polish government in exile; appointed translator and liaison officer to General Sikorski, the Prime Minister of the Polish Government-in-exile
Performs over 300 concerts for Allied troops, hospitals, POW centers, etc.
Serves as translator for General Sikorski's trip to Mexico to seek sanctuary for Polish refugees
Makes Carnegie Hall debut; gives Polish Relief recital
Invited to reorganize string department at the National University of Mexico
Appointed director of the string department at the National University of Mexico
Becomes a Mexican citizen
Meets and plays for Artur Rubinstein, who encourages him to resume his concert career; Rubinstein introduces Szeryng to Sol Hurok
Awarded Grand Prix du Disque
Makes a twenty-city United States concert tour
Becomes Mexican Cultural Ambassador
Awarded Grand Prix du Disque
Receives Médaille d'Argent de la Ville de Paris and Edison Award; becomes Officier d'Ordre des Arts et Lettres, Paris
Named Citizen of Honor, Richmond, Virginia
Henryk Szeryng Festival of Music is held in Mexico City
Appointed honorary director of the Conservatory of Music in Mexico City; decorated as Commander of the Order of the Finnish Lion in Helsinki for his promotion of the music of Sibelius
Awarded Grand Prix du Disque
Designated honorary member of the Royal Academy of Music, London
Appointed special music adviser to the Mexican delegation at UNESCO; receives citation from city of Philadelphia; awarded "Key to the City of Kansas City"
Receives "Wiener Floetenuhr" award and an "Edison" for a recording of Mozart violin concertos
Performs a "Salute to the Kennedy Center" on behalf of Mexico, and is named a "founder artist of the center"

Gives first performance since Paganini's time of rediscovered Violin concerto no. 3 with the London Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Gibson, coinciding with the release of the first recording of the work
Plays recital for UNICEF at Teatro Real in Madrid in presence of H.R.H. Princess Sofia of Spain and is presented with Alfonso El Sabio Cross
Receives the insignia of France's Légion d'Honneur

Donates his Stradivarius violin to the City of Jerusalem to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the State of Israel. The violin is to be loaned, for playing and performing, to outstanding young Israeli violinists
Named Honorary Citizen of Alicante (Spain)
Donates his Guarnerius "Sanctae Theresiae" violin to Mexican President Luis Echeverria to be used by gifted young Mexican violinists, preferably leaders of the Mexican National Symphony Orchestra
Receives citations from the city and county of Los Angeles
Named Citizen of Honor, San Luis Potosí
Teaches for two months of the year at the National University of Mexico; travels on a diplomatic passport as Mexican Cultural Ambassador
Named Citizen of Honor, city of Prades, for Festival of Prades; receives Citation from the city of Miami, Florida
Named Citizen of Honor, Poznan (Poland)
Receives Citation from the city of Kansas City
Celebrates "Golden Jubilee," for 50th year on the concert stage; sixty-concert tour; many special events, awards and citations
Marries Waltraud Büscher
Designated Officier de l'Ordre de St. Charles, Monaco; awarded "Key to the city of San Diego"
Receives Scroll of Honor from Israel Philharmonic
Named Officier de Légion d'Honneur
Appointed "Sagamore of the Wabash" in Indianapolis
Awarded Croix d’Or du Mérite de la République Populaire Polonaise
Designated Honorary Fellow, Israel Cancer Association
Dies in Kassel, West Germany of a cerebral hemorrhage

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Henrk Szeryng Collection documents the career of a great violinist who was also active as a teacher, a patron of the arts, and a diplomat. The bulk of the materials are Szeryng's collected musical scores, but also included are personal papers relating to activities other than musical performance. Various teaching and master-class materials in the collection date from his many years as an educator, and a number of speeches and writings reflect his active role as a public figure. Szeryng's generosity in supporting the arts and other worthy causes, as demonstrated by his donation of several valuable violins for use by promising young violinists and by his many benefit performances, is also well documented in the biographical articles and interviews of the collection.

The Music materials in the collection consist of both manuscript and printed scores. The bulk of the music is printed, but many of these scores and parts include Szeryng's handwritten annotations. The manuscripts include a number of Szeryng's own compositions, as well as his arrangements and revisions of both standard and little-known works. Among these is Paganini's Third violin concerto, a work which Szeryng himself rediscovered. Also of particular significance are the manuscripts of composers whose works Szeryng actively commissioned or promoted, such as Manuel Ponce and Cristóbal Halffter.

The Correspondence in the collection consists of letters between Szeryng and many prominent violinists, pianists, and conductors, including Isaac Stern, Shlomo Mintz, Yehudi Menuhin, Josef Gingold, Rafael Kubelik, Jean Martinon, Erich Leinsdorf, and Eugene Ormandy. The numerous personal friendships that Szeryng fostered in the various locations to which he travelled are reflected in correspondence from those acquaintances as well. The many official invitations indicate his prestige as both violinist and diplomat, and the letters of condolence received by Waltraud Szeryng following his death reflect the widespread sense of loss felt at his passing.

Szeryng's studies and teachings as a violinist are reflected in several papers and books detailing the principles of the Leopold Auer, Carl Flesch and Eugène Ysaye schools of violin playing. Szeryng's own views about violin technique are described in papers housed in both the Teaching Materials series and the Speeches & Writings series.

In the Performance Files of the collection, publicity materials provide an overview of the evolution of Szeryng's career. Representative concert programs and numerous clippings clearly document Szeryng's endeavors as a concert artist, diplomat and patron. The Business Records include many receipts, contracts, and financial statements that also reflect his concert and recording activities.

The remainder of the collection consists of various personal papers: more than a thousand photographs, many of Szeryng with other prominent musicians and diplomats or ambassadors; documentation of his career as a recording artist; numerous awards and citations; his scrapbooks; and all of the books from his personal library that pertain to his musical career or have noteworthy inscriptions.
